# packages/adapter-rust/vendor/codelldb/linux-x64/lldb/lib/python3.12/site-packages/pip/_vendor/rich/_palettes.py
@source-hash: 71d7afd4940a6742
@generated: 2026-02-09T18:01:40Z

## Purpose
Defines pre-configured color palettes for terminal text rendering in the Rich library. Provides RGB color data for different terminal color standards and systems.

## Key Components

### Color Palette Constants
- **WINDOWS_PALETTE (L5-24)**: 16-color palette matching Windows 10 ANSI escape code colors. Contains RGB tuples sourced from Wikipedia ANSI escape code documentation.
- **STANDARD_PALETTE (L27-46)**: Standard ANSI color palette with 16 colors including bright variants. Follows traditional ANSI color specifications with RGB values.
- **EIGHT_BIT_PALETTE (L50-309)**: Complete 256-color palette for 8-bit terminal color support. Includes:
  - Standard 16 colors (L52-67)
  - 216 color cube with systematic RGB progressions (L68-283) 
  - 24 grayscale colors (L284-308)

## Dependencies
- `Palette` class from `.palette` module (L1) - wraps color data in palette objects

## Architecture Notes
- All palettes are immutable module-level constants
- Colors stored as RGB tuples with values 0-255
- EIGHT_BIT_PALETTE follows standard 256-color terminal arrangement:
  - Colors 0-15: ANSI colors
  - Colors 16-231: 6×6×6 RGB color cube
  - Colors 232-255: Grayscale ramp
- Windows palette specifically targets Windows 10 terminal color rendering differences

## Usage Context
These palettes enable Rich to map high-level color specifications to appropriate RGB values for different terminal capabilities and operating systems.
